title: How do ions form? What is an example? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ll go wild and give you _two_ examples :) An ion is like a molecule, except that it has an electrical charge. This almost always means that it has unequal numbers of protons and electrons (there are other charged particles, such as positrons, but they hardly ever show up in ordinary chemistry). So if you have eight protons (which means you’re an oxygen atom) and nine electrons, you have a net charge of negative one, which makes you a negatively charged ion or “anion.” If you have eight protons but only five electrons, you have a net charge of +3, which makes you a cation. (Other people will tell you that it’s impossible to make O3+. They’re wrong :)) So — the first way an ion can form by having one of its electrons “knocked off” by an electromagnetic wave. Ordinarily you have to be a fairly strong wave to do this — there are a very few chemical structures that can be ionized by visible light, but almost all atoms and molecules require a harder hit, such as ultraviolet light or gamma radiation. If this happens to you, you lose an electron, which means you _lose_ a negative charge, so your net charge is now +1 and you’re a cation. This is a physical effect called “ionization,” but most people would agree that it’s not a chemical reaction, since only one atom is involved. The second way _is_ a chemical reaction. Let’s start with an electrically neutral sodium atom (atomic number 11) and a chlorine atom, which is also electrically neutral (with an atomic number of 35). For reasons you can read about in a chapter on the alkali metals, the sodium atom has a very pesky electron that it would love to get rid of — but it can’t just shoot it into space, because the electrostatic attraction between an electron and the resulting positively charged sodium ion would be _YUGE_. The electron would just change its mind and come back. (This actually happens — it’s called fluorescence.) However, if we mix it up with a chlorine atom as well, the story is very different. The chlorine atom is absolutely delighted to accept that extra electron (read about halogens to learn more). So now we have a much more friendly situation. The sodium atom gives up its pesky outer electron and becomes a sodium ion, Na+, and the chlorine atom accepts the electron and becomes a chloRIDE ion (Cl-). And they stick together — why? Because opposite charges attract. Now for a story. Little Miss Chlorine came home from school one day and her mommy said — “Why Miss Chlorine, you’ve grown an extra electron! You’ll need a whole closet of new dresses. How on earth did you let that happen? Have you been hanging out with that nasty Sodium again?” Miss Chlorine burst into tears and said, “Oh, Mommy — he just gave me a RIDE…”

Since the answers provided below seem inadequate, I will address some of the misconceptions in them. Ions, of course, are charged molecules (using the broad definition of molecule, which includes individual atoms). Ions are not “usually” formed from atoms. This is a misperception fomented by the way we teach chemistry. Chemistry is usually taught by teaching from the foundations upwards, so we start with elements, describe atoms, then move on to compounds, molecules and ions. But in the region of this planet in which we live, the biosphere, this is misleading. Here, compounds are the norm, and elements are very, very rare. A few elements can be found in their elemental states (O2, N2, Au, Ag, etc.) but the amounts found in the elemental state are often dwarfed by the amounts in the compound state. For example, the amount of oxygen in the earth’s atmosphere is dwarfed by the amount of oxygen in the Earth’s crust. You can find small pieces of elemental iron lying around, but the vast majority of the iron around us is in the form of iron compounds. The upshot of this is that where we live, compound forms of the elements are “normal” and elements are not. Similarly neutral atoms (being what the elements are made of) are not normal, but ions are. Take sodium, for example, which does not occur in nature in its elemental form, but its ionic form is ubiquitous. For example, about 1.5% of all of the ocean’s mass is sodium. So, the “chain of causation” of “atoms gain or lose electrons to become ions” is almost exactly backward. (As mentioned this is the order in which things were taught and since atoms are taught first, ions are linked back to the already taught atoms.) The odds are, in the case of Na+ ions, that those ions have been ions for millions if not billions of years and, if they have ever been transformed into atoms (by man, doesn’t happen to any extent naturally), they didn’t stay atoms for very long. Given any opportunity to interact with other chemicals, the sodium atoms revert back to their “normal” state, as ions, in a trice. So, if you are in a student in a beginning chemistry course, the answer you are probably expected to come up with is “atoms gain or lose electrons …” The only thing lacking in such an answer is the truth. This mistake of chemical pedagogy is amplified as “ionic bonding” is discussed which, in beginning chemistry classes, is almost always described using electron-transfer reactions, e.g. Na + Cl2 = NaCl, which is also far from being true. If you want to see ionic bonding in action, just evaporate some seawater (or salt water). As the water evaporates, the ions present bond with one another to make crystals. No electron transfers are involved.

response.answer_text: An ion is formed when an atom loses electrons (oxidation) or gains electrons (reduction). An ion is a particles with uneven number of protons and electrons. Since proton number cannot be changed through chemical means, forming an ion requires gaining or losing of electrons. This can occur in a redox (reduce and oxidize) reaction. —Gt. Yuhan Zhang (Proud A-level Chemistry student)

Ions are electrically charged particles formed when atoms lose or gain electrons. They have the same electronic structures as noble gases. Metal atoms form positiveions, while non-metal atoms form negative ions. The strong electrostatic forces of attraction between oppositely charged ions are called ionic bonds.
